abstract.text: Apply back pressure to precisely control when publishers produce elements.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: In Combine, a
produces elements, and a
acts on the elements it receives. However, a publisher can’t send elements until
the subscriber attaches and asks for them. The subscriber also controls the rate
at which the publisher delivers elements, by using the
type to indicate how many elements it can receive. A subscriber can indicate demand
in either of two ways:
By calling
on the
instance that the publisher provided when the subscriber first subscribed.
By returning a new demand when the publisher calls the subscriber’s
method to deliver an element.
Demand is additive: If a subscriber has demanded two elements, and then requests
, the publisher’s unsatisfied demand is now five elements.
If the publisher then sends an element, the unsatisfied demand decreases to four.
Publishing elements is the only way to reduce unsatisfied demand; subscribers can’t
request negative demand.
Many apps just use the operators
and
to create the convenience
subscriber types
and
respectively. These two subscribers issue a demand for
when they first attach to the publisher. Once a publisher has unlimited demand, there
can be no further negotiation of demand between subscriber and publisher.

content.text: Consume Elements as the Publisher Produces Them

inlineContent.text: When a publisher has high or unlimited demand, it could send elements faster than
a subscriber can process them. This scenario could lead to elements being dropped,
or rapidly increasing memory pressure as elements fill a buffer while they await
processing.
This scenario can occur if you use the convenience subscribers, because they demand
an unlimited number of elements. Ensure that the closure you provide to
and the side-effects of
adhere
to the following traits:
Don’t block the publisher.
Don’t consume excessive memory by buffering elements.
Don’t get overwhelmed and fail to process elements.
Fortunately, many commonly used publishers, such as publishers associated with user-interface
elements, publish at a manageable rate. Other common publishers only produce a single
element, like the URL Loading System’s
It’s perfectly safe to use sink and assign subscribers with these publishers.

content.text: Apply Back Pressure with a Custom Subscriber

inlineContent.text: To control the rate at which the publisher sends elements to your subscriber, create
a custom implementation of the
protocol. Use
your implementation to specify demands that you know your subscriber can keep up
with. As the subscriber receives elements, it can request more by returning a new
demand value to
, or by calling
on the subscription. With either,
your subscriber can then fine-tune the number of elements the publisher can send
it at any given time.
This concept of controlling flow by signaling a subscriber’s readiness to receive
elements is called
back pressure
Each publisher keeps track of its current unsatisfied demand, meaning how many more
elements a subscriber has requested. Even automated sources like Foundation’s
only produce elements when they have pending demand. The following example code illustrates
this behavior.

code: // Publisher: Uses a timer to emit the date once per second.
// Subscriber: Waits 5 seconds after subscription, then requests a

inlineContent.text: The subscriber’s
implementation uses a five-second delay
before it requests any elements from the publisher. During this period, the publisher
exists and has a valid subscriber, but has zero demand, so it doesn’t produce elements.
It only starts publishing elements after the delay expires and the subscriber gives
it a nonzero demand, as seen in the following output:
This example only requests three elements, issuing the demand after the five-second
delay expires. As a result, the publisher sends no further elements after the third,
but also doesn’t complete publishing by sending a
value either, because the publisher is just waiting for more demand. To continue
to receive elements, the subscriber could store the subscription and periodically
request more elements. It could also indicate new demand as the return value from
its
implementation.

content.text: Manage Unlimited Demand by Using Back-Pressure Operators

inlineContent.text: Even without writing a custom
, you can still
apply back pressure by using one of Combine’s buffering or timing operators:
holds onto
a fixed number of items from an upstream publisher. When full, the buffer either
drops elements or throws an error.
publishes
only when the upstream publisher stops publishing for a specified interval of time.
produces elements
at a given maximum rate. If it receives multiple elements during an interval, it
sends only the newest or oldest.
and
bundle elements until they exceed a given count or time interval, sending you an
array of elements. This option is good if your subscriber can process multiple elements
at the same time.
Because these operators control the number of elements your subscriber receives,
you can attach a subscriber that requests unlimited elements, such as
and

abstract.text: Customize handling of asynchronous events by combining event-processing operators.
A type-erasing subscriber.
Declares that a type can transmit a sequence of values over time.
Assigns each element from a publisher to a property on an object.
Buffers elements received from an upstream publisher.
Collects up to the specified number of elements, and then emits a single array of the collection.
Collects elements by a given time-grouping strategy, and emits a single array of the collection.
Publishes elements only after a specified time interval elapses between events.
Attaches a subscriber with closure-based behavior to a publisher that never fails.
Publishes either the most-recent or first element published by the upstream publisher in the specified time interval.
A protocol that declares a type that can receive input from a publisher.
Tells the subscriber that the publisher has produced an element.
A namespace for types that serve as subscribers.
A simple subscriber that assigns received elements to a property indicated by a key path.
The publisher finished normally.
A requested number of items, sent to a publisher from a subscriber through the subscription.
A request for as many values as the publisher can produce.
A simple subscriber that requests an unlimited number of values upon subscription.
A protocol representing the connection of a subscriber to a publisher.
Tells a publisher that it may send more values to the subscriber.
A namespace for symbols related to subscriptions.
A publisher that repeatedly emits the current date on a given interval.
A publisher that delivers the results of performing URL session data tasks.
